definition: lit. rich country, strong army (idiom); slogan of legalist philosophers in pre-Han times/Make the country wealthy and the military powerful, slogan of modernizers in Qing China and Meiji Japan (Japanese pronunciation: Fukoku kyōhei)
strong/powerful/better/slightly more than/vigorous/violent/best in their category, e.g. see 百強|百强[bai3 qiang2]
to force/to compel/to strive/to make an effort

sentences.english: Meanwhile, as Fuchai’s kingdom declined, Yue grew rich and raised a new army.
sentences.chinese: 与此同时，当夫差的王国每况愈下，越国则富国强兵。

definition: to change the laws/political reform/unconventional method
Shang Yang's political reform of Qin state 秦國|秦国 of 356 BC and 350 BC, that put it on the road to world domination

Shang Yang (c. 390-338 BC), legalist philosopher and statesman of the state of Qin 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], whose reforms paved the way for the eventual unification of the Chinese empire by the Qin dynasty 秦朝|秦朝[Qin2 chao2]
to engage in wars of aggression at will (idiom)/militaristic/bellicose
Li Kui (455-395 BC), legalist philosopher and statesman of Wei state 魏國|魏国[Wei4 guo2]
Duke Xiao of Qin, 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], ruled 361-338 BC during the Warring States Period
the state of Qin, one of the seven states of the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Hundred Days Reform (1898), failed attempt to reform the Qing dynasty
to bring peace and stability to the country
